docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Damian Ivers, a tour-boat owner here, injured his back in August, he didn't go to a doctor's office; he logged on to eSalveo.com, an e-health Web site. He sent a description of his symptoms to his family doctor, who replied through eSalveo, a privately owned site that allows patients to communicate electronically with their doctors for a fee, opting out of the free government health care. ''My doctor diagnosed it as a muscle injury and suggested putting ice on it,'' Mr. Ivers said, who is 31. ''It cost me $20, but my time is worth a lot more than that.''

headline.main: Feel Under the Weather in Canada? Log On for an Electronic House Call

docs.abstract: eSalveo.com, privately owned Canadian Web site, allows patients to communicate electronically with their doctors for a fee, thus opting out of free government health care; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST about everybody agrees that managed health care is ailing and needs to be fixed. Employers dislike the rising expenses and responsibility, and consumers and doctors hate the restrictions. Seeing an opportunity, several Web companies are offering new ways to pay for medical services. For example, several thousand employees of the Aon Corporation, an insurance broker based in Chicago, have had a chance this month to test an approach called a defined contribution plan. Besides Aon's usual roster of choices, Aon workers in Chicago and Minneapolis can select a combination of pretax cash for everyday health care needs, plus a high-deductible insurance policy for catastrophes.

headline.main: Redefining Coverage to Cut Out the Middleman

docs.abstract: Several Web companies offer innovative ways to pay for medical services (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Never before have Vermont's autumn colors blazed so hot, some here are saying proudly these brilliant gilded days. Unfortunately, the same goes for Vermont's politics, others are saying with concern. From local races to the three-way contest for governor, this campaign season has a supercharged feel to many Vermonters, and not in a pleasant way.
docs.abstract: Many people are calling unsually polarized election in Vermont referendum on civil unions law, which has made state first to offer gay couples virtually all legal rights and benefits of marriage; law has galvanized opposition to some other recent changes; Gov Howard Dean, Democrat, backs law, while his Republican challenger, Ruth Dwyer, opposes civil unions; third-party candidate, Anthony Pollina, backs law, but could deny Dean majority he needs to keep Legislature from choosing next governor; slim Democratic majorities that control both legislative houses may not survive election; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INSURANCE means more than insurance companies, and different sectors are experimenting with the Internet in different ways. Here are some snapshots of recent activities by the government and private industry, by for-profit and nonprofit health maintenance organizations and by Blue Cross and Blue Shield. HEALTH CARE FINANCING ADMINISTRATION -- One big step toward widespread electronic processing of insurance claims came in August, when the agency, which runs Medicare and Medicaid, proposed a standard format to streamline the processing of health care claims throughout the industry.

headline.main: Moving Beyond The Basics: Internet as Tool For Innovation

docs.abstract: Government and private health insurers experiment with Internet in different ways; activities at Health Care Financing Administration, Oxford Health Plans, Kaiser Permanente (HMO), Blue Cross and Blue Shield and General Motors noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Rick A. Lazio today intensified his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton's failed health care reform effort six years ago, unleashing a new series of advertisements and deriding her effort as ''bad medicine for New York.'' The multipronged offensive, 15 days before the election, represented an effort by Mr. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, to attack his Democratic opponent on an issue his advisers say is among Mrs. Clinton's most vulnerable.

headline.main: Lazio and Clinton Take Each Other to Task on Health Care

docs.abstract: Representative Rick A Lazio intensifies his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton's failed health care reform effort six years ago, unleashing new series of advertisements and deriding her effort as 'bad medicine for New York;' Clinton fires back by criticizing Lazio's Congressional voting record on health care issues, saying bills he supported would have deprived New Yorkers of billions of dollars in health financing; photo (M)

If any toiler in the health care system deserves far more credit than he or she receives, it is the person who cares for an ailing loved one at home.

docs.lead_paragraph: Advocacy groups have won overwhelming bipartisan support in Congress and passage of a bill to provide health care to thousands of women with breast cancer. Now they are pleading with President Clinton to sign the bill he supports in a public ceremony at the White House, to publicize the benefits that will become available to low-income women. But Mr. Clinton will sign the bill in private, White House officials said tonight. A major reason, they said, is that they want to avoid the awkwardness of inviting Representative Rick A. Lazio, an influential advocate for the bill, who is running against Hillary Rodham Clinton in the New York race for the Senate.

headline.main: Quiet Signing for Cancer Bill That Was Backed by Lazio

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will sign in private White House ceremony bill to provide health care to thousands of women with breast cancer; will ignore urgings of advocacy groups that won overwhelming bipartisan support for bill and its passage in Congress that he sign it in public to publicize benefits available to low-income women; White House officials cite need to avoid awkwardness of inviting Republican Repr Rick Lazio, influential advocate for bill, who is running against Hillary Rodham Clinton in New York race for US Senate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE GREEN PARTY A MESSAGE TO NADER VOTERS -- Ralph Nader supporters who worry that they could tip the presidential election to the Republicans are being told in a new advertising campaign that a ''vote for Nader is not a vote for Bush.'' Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate, currently draws about 4 percent in national polls, and some Democrats fear he could siphon enough votes from Vice President Al Gore to give Gov. George W. Bush of Texas the edge in several states with close races.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a small room on the ninth floor of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan, volunteers come to eat in the name of science. They sip milkshakes through polyethylene straws. They munch on baked chicken, sliced apples, potato chips and chocolate cake. They finish off meals composed entirely of Breyer's ice cream.

headline.main: Watching Volunteers, Experts Seek Clues to Eating Disorders

docs.abstract: Article in series The Fat Epidemic describes scientific studies on eating disorders at St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan and elsewhere; scientist probe why some people are able to control how much they eat, while others seem helpless to stop, how eating patterns of peple with anorexia or bulimia differ from those of other people, how dieting to lose or maintain weight relates to more extreme eating behavior, and when normal eating behavior crosses the line into the abnormal; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Jon S. Corzine continues to court elderly voters in minimalls and laborers in union halls across New Jersey, his Republican rival for the United States Senate, Representative Bob Franks, has been receiving glowing testimonials from his own most ardent supporters: Republicans from out of state. After appearing with former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York on Sunday, Mr. Franks campaigned today with Senators Don Nickles of Oklahoma and John W. Warner of Virginia in Warren County, where Mr. Franks trumpeted his vote for the so-called Social Security ''lock box'' at a retirement center.

headline.main: Corzine Woos the Elderly; Rival Woos Donors

docs.abstract: Jon S Corzine continues to court elderly voters in mini malls and laborers in union halls across New Jersey while his Republican rival for United States Senate, Representative Bob Franks, receives glowing testimonials from out of state supporters, including Sen Bob Dole, New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York State Gov George Pataki; photo (M)
